original_data.question: A 29-year-old woman presents to her primary care doctor with a lesion on her left labia. She first noticed the lesion 3 days ago. The patient describes the lesion as painful and swollen. She denies vaginal discharge. Her past medical history is notable for mild intermittent asthma, gout, and obesity. She uses an albuterol inhaler as needed and takes allopurinol. She has had 5 sexual partners in the past year and uses the pull-out method for contraception. She has a 10-pack-year smoking history and drinks 10-12 alcoholic beverages per week. On exam, she has an ulcerated, tender, and purulent ulcer on the left labia majora. The patient has mild unilateral painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. This patient's condition is most likely caused by which of the following pathogens?

model_response:
The clinical presentation is consistent with a painful genital ulcer with inguinal lymphadenopathy. The most common cause of genital ulcers in sexually active individuals is herpes simplex virus type 2. However, the clinical presentation of chancroid is very similar to that of genital herpes. Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid. It is a painful genital ulcer with inguinal lymphadenopathy. The lymph nodes may become fluctuant and rupture, forming buboes. The causative organism is a gram-negative coccobacillus. The treatment of choice is erythromycin. The other organisms are not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.

A medical professional who provides, coordinates, or helps a patient access a range of health care services. This is usually a medical doctor (MD), but may also be a Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine, nurse practitioner, clinical nurse specialist, or physician assistant, as allowed under state law.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
A part of the external female genitalia consisting of the labia majora and the labia minora.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation
A common gynecologic disorder characterized by an abnormal, nonbloody discharge from the genital tract.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Metabolic disorder characterized by recurrent acute arthritis, hyperuricemia and deposition of sodium urate in and around the joints, sometimes with formation of URIC ACID calculi.

A status with BODY WEIGHT that is grossly above the recommended standards, usually due to accumulation of excess FATS in the body. The standards may vary with age, sex, genetic or cultural background. In the BODY MASS INDEX, a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese, and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese (MORBID OBESITY).

A short-acting beta-2 adrenergic agonist that is primarily used as a bronchodilator agent to treat ASTHMA. Albuterol is prepared as a racemic mixture of R(-) and S(+) stereoisomers. The stereospecific preparation of R(-) isomer of albuterol is referred to as levalbuterol.
A device by means of which a medicinal product can be administered by inspiration through the nose or the mouth.
A XANTHINE OXIDASE inhibitor that decreases URIC ACID production. It also acts as an antimetabolite on some simpler organisms.
Married or single individuals who share sexual relations.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.

Prevention of CONCEPTION by blocking fertility temporarily, or permanently (STERILIZATION, REPRODUCTIVE). Common means of reversible contraception include NATURAL FAMILY PLANNING METHODS; CONTRACEPTIVE AGENTS; or CONTRACEPTIVE DEVICES.
The history of when and what an individual smoke(s) or smoked.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.
Drinkable liquids containing ETHANOL.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
An appraisal or evaluation of a patient's condition by a clinician that is based on a physical exam, medical history, and the patient's account of symptoms.
A lesion on the surface of the skin or a mucous surface, produced by the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue.
Applied to pain that is tender, i.e., elicited by touching the affected body part. []
A part of the external female genitalia consisting of the labia majora and the labia minora.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Involving only one part or side.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
An agent of disease; a disease producer.
